instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the radar classification of various materials using a broadband millimeter-wave complementary-metal-oxide semiconductor (CMOS) integrated receiver?
Output: The radar classification of various materials used a broadband millimeter-wave spectrum. Specifically, the radar operated in the W-band, which refers to a frequency range of 75-110 GHz.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the radar classification of various materials using a broadband millimeter-wave complementary-metal-oxide semiconductor (CMOS) integrated receiver?
Output: Three supervised machine learning tools were trained by the recorded data to classify materials into different categories.

instruction: What metric was chosen and how far can this metric go in the radar classification of various materials using a broadband millimeter-wave complementary-metal-oxide semiconductor (CMOS) integrated receiver?
Output: The metric chosen for radar classification of various materials using a broadband millimeter-wave CMOS integrated receiver is the accuracy level. The accuracy levels achieved in material classification were higher than 96%, and in thickness classification were 88%.

instruction: How were the machine learning models trained in the radar classification of various materials using a broadband millimeter-wave complementary-metal-oxide semiconductor (CMOS) integrated receiver?
Output: The machine learning models were trained using the recorded data from the broadband millimeter-wave CMOS integrated receiver. The receiver recorded the transmitted power through multiple solid materials at various distances from the receiver in the W-band (75-110 GHz). Three supervised machine learning tools were trained using this recorded data to classify the materials into different categories.
